newsitem.title: UK: BSkyB plans Pearson bid - report.
newsitem.headline: BSkyB plans Pearson bid - report.

text.p: Satellite broadcaster BSkyB is planning a bid worth more than four billion stg for British media company Pearson, the Independent reported on Monday.
The front-page report said the bid preparations were at an early stage and it added that they were believed to have been mounted in cooperation with a U.S.-based media company.
Rupert Murdoch's News Corp is the leading shareholder in satellite television company BSkyB, with a 40 percent stake. A BSkyB spokesman declined comment on the report.
Pearson owns the Financial Times newspaper, Penguin Books and a number of television production companies. Its current market capitalisation is just under four billion stg.

It hit the headlines last week when it appointed American Marjorie Scardino as its chief executive to succeed Frank Barlow from January 1. She becomes the first woman head of a top 100 British company.
BSkyB has developed into one of British leading companies in the 1990s and now has a market capitalisation of almost 12 billion stg.
The report said that Pearson was discounting a full bid from BSkyB, believing instead that its real target was the company's television interests.
But the report added that BSkyB was understood to be interested in retaining the Financial Times and buying the 50 percent of the Economist which Pearson does not own.
It said remaining assets such as theme parks and Penguin books would be sold off.

BSkyB's advisers Goldman Sachs are believed to have already started to purchase Pearson shares as a prelude to a bid, the report said. It said BSkyB might eventually have to pay up to six billion stg to capture Pearson.
